answers.answer: Vitamin D needs to be at least 32ng/mL to absorb calcium and between 40 to 60 ng/mL for cancer prevention.  Ferritin that low can cause hair loss as well.I felt SO bad when I was pre diabetic. I already had severe insulin resistance to start with due to a high % of sugar in my diet (not that I overate) but was pre diabetic due to hyperthyroidism (too much thyroid hormone in the blood). As I found out the hard way, high insulin prevents weight loss.  I also had plenty of symptoms from magnesium deficiency since excess insulin/blood glucose can cause excess magnesium to be excreted.Excerpt from Primary Care Physicans - Pre Diabetes..."Many people with pre-diabetes suffer no identifiable symptoms of which they are aware. However, some do have episodes of hypoglycemia, which can cause periods of lightheadedness or dizziness, hot flashes or chills, tremors in the hands, anxiety or nervousness, headaches, sweats, palpitations (sensation of a rapid or irregular heart beat), and fatigue or exhaustion. Body aches may also occur, as do occasional painful muscle spasms (such as "charlie horses"), abdominal cramps, urgency to urinate or defecate, nausea, and sometimes other gastrointestinal symptoms. Mood swings are also frequent with rapid variations in blood sugar, and patients may experience emotional highs and lows all occurring within a 30 to 120 minute period. "
Please post the reference ranges for all your thyroid tests.  Ranges vary lab to lab, so they have to come from your own lab report.

Thank you for replying.Lab value ranges                   My resultT3 uptake (22-35%)                                 24T4 total (4.5-12.0)                        7.5Free T4 (1.4-3.8)                         1.8TSH(.45-4.5)                                .84

Would you recheck your FT4 range?  3.8 is a very high upper limit for the range.Assuming the range is correct, your FT4 is only 17% of range, which is very low.  Based on when we felt relief of symptoms, many of us found that FT4 had to be around 50% of range.T3U, which despite its name is an indirect measure of T4, is considered an obsolete test as is TT4.  Your doctor should also be testing FT3, which is the test that correlates best with symptoms.  TPOab and TGab, to determine Hashi's, would also be good.

question: I am so frustrated and am hopeful that anyone out there can be of assistance. For the last couple of years, I have been feeling horrible.  Fatigued, severe hot flashes, erratic heart rate feeling as if i have a butterfly or skipping beat with a cough or feeling dizzy (heart rate down in the 50's), last but not least weight gain plus 20lbs over the last 2 years.  My pcp ordered a holter monitor and PAC's were diagnosed.  I finally got to see an internist after above plus acute loss of hair and continued dizziness.  I asked for my TFTs to be drawn and my results were as follows:  TSH .8, Free T3 uptake 24, T4 total 7.5, Free T4 1.8, Ferratin 28, vitamin D 25.  I was told everything was within normal limits and labs to be rechecked in 3 months.  Gyno exam normal.  I was put on Metformin for A1c of 6.9.  Are these vague diabetic related symptoms or is there a thyroid component as well here?  Thank you for any insight you may be able to give.  I'm so tired of feeling horrible.
title: Wit's end.  Is this thyroid?
